Database.Title: SEED Bioinformatics Database
Database.Notes: [p]The SEED database manages bio-informatics data imported from exchange files. It contains information that can be used to derive subsystem spreadsheets and support annotation of genomes. The annotation is three-tiered: for each protein, we recognize a [i]privileged[/i] annotation, which is curated by a human expert, a [i]projected[/i] annotation which is computed by annotation software, and a [i]non-priviliged[/i] annotation which is proposed by the user community.[/p] [p]The diagram colors indicate the general category of data.[/p] [list] [b]Red[/b] Genome group: includes all taxonomy and sequence data.[*] [b]Blue[/b] Annotation group: includes the subsystems and all the functions and roles.[*] [b]Green[/b] Feature group: includes features, protein sequences, and related publications.[*] [b]Navy[/b] Chemistry group: includes reactions and compounds. [/list]

Entity.name: Genome
Entity.Notes: A genome represents a specific organism with DNA, or a specific meta-genome. All DNA sequences in the database belong to genomes.

Field.name: core
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a core genome, else FALSE. Annotation data is projected from core genomes.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: Full genus/species/strain name of the genome, occasionally containing notes from the uploader.

Field.name: dna-size
Field.Notes: Number of base pairs in the genome.

Field.name: contigs
Field.Notes: Number of contigs for this genome.

Field.name: md5-identifier
Field.Notes: MD5 identifier for this genome, for comparison with genomes in other databases. The MD5 is computed by taking the MD5s of the contigs, lexically sorting them, joining them together with commas, and computing a hex MD5 of the result.

Field.name: gc-content
Field.Notes: Percent GC content present in the genome's DNA.

Field.name: contig-file
Field.Notes: Name of the file containing the genome's contig FASTA, relative to the repository root.

Field.name: prokaryotic
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a prokaryotic genome, else FALSE.

Field.name: domain
Field.Notes: Domain for this genome-- Eukaryota, Archaea, Bacteria, etc.

Field.name: genetic-code
Field.Notes: Genetic code for translating this genome's coding features to proteins.

Index.Notes: This index allows searching for genomes by name.
This index allows searching for genomes by MD5 identifier.
This index presents the core genomes first in sequence.

Entity.name: Contig
Entity.Notes: A contig is a contiguous sequence of base pairs belonging to a single genome. The key of the contig is the genome ID followed by a colon and then the contig ID. The contig's DNA information is located in a flat file on disk named "contigs.fa" in the directory named by the parent genome.

Field.name: length
Field.Notes: Number of base pairs in the contig.

Field.name: md5-identifier
Field.Notes: MD5 identifier of this contig, for comparison with contigs in other databases. This is a standard hex MD5 of the contig DNA sequence.

Index.Notes: This index allows searching for contigs by MD5 identifier.

Entity.name: Feature
Entity.Notes: A feature (sometimes also called a gene) is a part of a genome that is of special interest. Features may be spread across multiple DNA sequences (contigs) of a genome, but never across more than one genome. Each feature in the database has a unique FIG ID that functions as its ID in this table.

Field.name: feature-type
Field.Notes: Code indicating the type of this feature. Among the codes currently supported are "peg" for a protein encoding gene, "bs" for a binding site, "opr" for an operon, and so forth.

Field.name: sequence-length
Field.Notes: Number of base pairs in this feature.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: An alternative name for the feature. These are frequently ambiguous or incomplete.

Field.name: checksum
Field.Notes: An MD5 checksum of the feature's original function when it was loaded. This is used to compare it to the original data.

Index.Notes: This index is used to find a feature by alias name.

Entity.name: Protein
Entity.Notes: A protein sequence is a specific sequence of amino acids. Unlike a DNA sequence, a protein sequence does not belong to a genome. Identical proteins generated by different genomes are stored as a single Protein instance. The key is a hex MD5 hash code computed from the protein letter sequence.

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: The sequence contains the letters corresponding to the protein's amino acids.

Entity.name: TaxonomicGrouping
Entity.Notes: A taxonomic grouping is a segment of the classification for an organism. Taxonomic groupings are organized into a strict hierarchy by the IsGroupContaining relationship.

Field.name: domain
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a domain grouping, else FALSE.

Field.name: hidden
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a hidden grouping, else FALSE. Hidden groupings are not typically shown in a lineage list.

Field.name: scientific-name
Field.Notes: Primary scientific name for this grouping. This is the name used when displaying a taxonomy.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: Alternate name for this grouping. A grouping may have many alternate names. The scientific name should also be in this list.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to find a particular taxonomic grouping by name. Because the scientifc name is also an alias, there is no index on scientific name.

Entity.name: GenomeSet
Entity.Notes: A genome set is a named group of related genomes.
Entity.Asides: Each genome set consists of genomes that use highly similar ribosomal small subunits. Two genomes are in the same set if they have a similarity of 97% or greater in subunits of length 1000 or more.

Entity.name: Function
Entity.Notes: A function is a set of roles that represent the effects of a protein. Most functions consist of a single role, but many can have two or three roles. The key is the set of role IDs joined by the separator. Thus, a function ID is directly computable from its role IDs.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: Text of the function, consisting of the roles strung together in sequence with separator characters in between.

Field.name: sep
Field.Notes: Separator character for this function's roles. [b]/[/b] for multiple roles by different domains, [b]@[/b] for multiple roles by the same domain, or [b];[/b] when the function performs one of several roles but the precise one cannot be determined. For a single-function role, a space is used. For a malformed or hypothetical function (which has no roles) a hyphen is used.

Entity.name: Role
Entity.Notes: A role represents a single effect of a protein in a cell. The fundamental purpose of annotation is to assign roles to proteins. The collection of roles (often only one) associated with a protein is the protein's function. Each role is assigned a short string key. The key is a UUID.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: textual description of the role

Field.name: ec-number
Field.Notes: EC number of this role (if any)

Field.name: tc-number
Field.Notes: transporter classification of this role (if any)

Field.name: hypo
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a hypothetical role, else FALSE

Field.name: checksum
Field.Notes: Checksum for this role. The role is first normalized by converting it to lower case and removing extra spaces, EC numbers, and TC numbers. Then an MD5 is computed.

Index.Notes: This index allows searching for roles by the checksum string.
This index allows searching through roles by EC number.
This index allows searching through roles by TC number.
This index allows searching through roles by text. It can be used with LIKE-style queries to find similar roles.

Entity.name: Subsystem
Entity.Notes: A subsystem is a collection of roles that work together in a cell. Identification of subsystems is an important tool for recognizing parallel genetic features in different organisms. The key is a short string constructed from the original name.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The readable name of the subsystem.
Field.Asides: The subsystem name used to come in two forms-- a natural form with spaces and an internal form with underscores. In this database we will only have the natural form.

Field.name: privileged
Field.Notes: TRUE if the subsystem can only be modified by privileged users; FALSE if the subsystem can be modified by anyone.

Field.name: version
Field.Notes: Version number for the subsystem. This value is incremented each time the subsystem is backed up.

Field.name: checksum
Field.Notes: Checksum for this subsystem, formed from the subsystem name.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to find the subsystem by name. Note that no two subsystems can have the same name.
This index allows the user to find the subsystem by checksum.

Entity.name: SubsystemRow
Entity.Notes: A subsystem row represents an implementation of a subsystem in a genome. A genome could conceivably have more than one such implementation The key is the subsystem ID followed by a colon and a unique identifying number.
Entity.Asides: A genome could have multiple instances of a subsystem either because they are at different privilege levels (public, privileged, or projects) or because the subsystem occurs in different regions of the genome (as may be the case when an instance of the the subsystem really belongs to a phage). Also note that vacant subsystem rows (variant code -1 in SEED) are not stored in this database.

Field.name: privilege
Field.Notes: privilege level of the function assignments from which the subsystem instance was constructed: 0 (public), 1 (projected), or 2 (privileged)

Field.name: needs-curation
Field.Notes: TRUE if the subsystem row needs to be validated or examined for errors. This flag is frequently set when the subsystem row has recently been projected by an automated program.

Field.name: variant-code
Field.Notes: the variant code indicating which form of the subsystem is represented by this row.

Entity.name: SubsystemCell
Entity.Notes: A subsystem cell represents a single role in a subsystem row. It contains one or more features from the row's genome. The key is the row ID followed by a colon and the role abbreviation.

Entity.name: Reaction
Entity.Notes: A reaction is a chemical process that converts one set of compounds (substrate) to another set (products). The reaction ID is generally a small number preceded by a letter. A reversible reaction is entered as two separate reactions so that each direction can be associated with the appropriate roles.

Entity.name: Compound
Entity.Notes: A compound is a chemical that participates in a reaction. All compounds have a unique ID and may also have one or more names. Both ligands and reaction components are treated as compounds.

Field.name: label
Field.Notes: Primary name of the compound.

Field.name: ubiquitous
Field.Notes: TRUE if this compound is found in most reactions, else FALSE

Index.Notes: This index allows searching for compounds by name.

Relationship.name: IsInTaxonomicGroup
Relationship.Notes: This relationship imposes a hierarchy on taxonomic groupings. Each group can contain one or more subgroups. A group with no subgroups is a leaf. There is a hidden root group at the top. The subgroups of that group are domains.

Relationship.name: Taxonomy2Genome
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the taxonomic group to which it belongs. The taxonomic group is computed from the genome ID where possible, and the genome name otherwise. It can also be specified explicitly in the genome exchange files.

Field.name: confidence
Field.Notes: This indicates how confident we are in the taxonomic assignment. A value of [b]2[/b] means there is an exact match on name or genome ID. A value of [b]1[/b] means there was a close match near the node chosen. A value of [b]0[/b] means we had to guess.

Relationship.name: Set2Genome
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the single set to which it belongs. One of the genomes will be considered a representative of the set. That information is stored in this relationship.

Field.name: representative
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is relationship connects to the representative genome of the set, else FALSE.

FromIndex.Notes: This index presents the genomes of the set in order with the representative first.

Relationship.name: Genome2Feature
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genomes to the points of interest (features) in its DNA.

Relationship.name: Protein2Feature
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to its protein translation.

Relationship.name: Feature2Contig
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to the DNA segments that comprise it. Normally there is only one such segment, but eukaryotes will tend to have features with multiple segments.

Field.name: ordinal
Field.Notes: Sequence number of this segment, starting from 0 and proceeding sequentially forward from there.

Field.name: begin
Field.Notes: Index (1-based) of the first residue in the contig that belongs to the segment.
Field.Asides: The begin value is not the start residue, it is the leftmost residue. If the direction is backward, it will actually be the end residue.

Field.name: len
Field.Notes: Length of this segment.

Field.name: dir
Field.Notes: Direction (strand) of the segment: [b]+[/b] if it is forward and [b]-[/b] if it is backward.

FromIndex.Notes: This index presents the segments of the feature in the correct order.

ToIndex.Notes: This index presents the segments on a contig in order of the start position.

Relationship.name: Function2Role
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a function to its constituent roles. Most functions consist of a single role, but some can connect to several roles.

Relationship.name: Subsystem2Role
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem to its constituent roles. The relationship specifies the role abbreviation and its ordinal position in the subsystem path.

Field.name: ordinal
Field.Notes: Ordinal position of this role (from 0) in the columns of the populated subsystem

Field.name: abbr
Field.Notes: Abbreviation for the subsystem role name.

FromIndex.Notes: This index presents the roles in pathway order.

Relationship.name: Genome2Contig
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to its constituent contigs. The full set of contigs comprises the DNA sequence of the genome.

Relationship.name: Feature2Function
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to its function. Only features which do not produce proteins will be connected to functions, as the primary function assignment is to proteins.

Field.name: security
Field.Notes: Privilege level of the annotation. [b]0[/b] for a non-privileged (public) annotation, [b]1[/b] for a projected annotation, and [b]2[/b] for a privileged annotation.

Field.name: comment
Field.Notes: A comment by the annotator about this functional assignment.

FromIndex.Notes: This index insures only one function of each privilege is assigned to a feature.

Relationship.name: Role2Reaction
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a role to the reactions that take place when the role is expressed.

Field.name: model-id
Field.Notes: ID of the reaction instance in the modeling system.

Relationship.name: Reaction2Compound
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a reaction to the compounds that participate in it. A reaction involves many compounds, and a compound can be involved in many reactions. The relationship attributes indicate whether a compound is a product or substrate of the reaction, as well as its stoichiometry.

Field.name: product
Field.Notes: TRUE if the compound is a product of the reaction, FALSE if it is a substrate. When a reaction is written on paper in chemical notation, the substrates are left of the arrow and the products are to the right. Sorting on this field will cause the substrates to appear first, followed by the products.

Field.name: stoichiometry
Field.Notes: Number of molecules of the compound that participate in a single instance of the reaction. For example, if a reaction produces two water molecules, the stoichiometry of water for the reaction would be two. When a reaction is written on paper in chemical notation, the stoichiometry is the number next to the chemical formula of the compound.

Field.name: cofactor
Field.Notes: TRUE if the compound is a cofactor; FALSE if it is a major component of the reaction.

ToIndex.Notes: This index presents the compounds in the reaction in the order they should be displayed when writing it in chemical notation. All the substrates appear before all the products, and within that ordering, the main compounds appear first.

Relationship.name: Genome2Row
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem row to the genome which it populates. A subsystem's occurrence in a genome is only represented if it is considered relatively important for annotation analysis and projection.

Relationship.name: Feature2Cell
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to the subsystem spreadsheet cells it occupies.

Relationship.name: Subsystem2Row
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem to its populated spreadsheet rows. Each row represents the implementation of a subsystem in a genome by particular features. Thus, this relationship connects a subsystem to its implementations of interest.

Relationship.name: Row2Cell
Relationship.Notes: This relationship yields all the cells (one per role) in a subsystem spreadsheet row.

Field.name: ordinal
Field.Notes: ordinal position (0-based) of this cell's role in the subsystem's role list

FromIndex.Notes: This index presents the cells of a subsystem row in role order.

Relationship.name: Role2Cell
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem cell to the role its features perform.
